Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Malicious Behavior Detection in Hybrid Dynamic Spectrum Access

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
To tackle the ever-increasing spectrum scarcity issue, dynamic spectrum access is envisioned as a set of promising new spectrum management paradigms. Although it has enabled the opportunistic access of underutilized licensed bands, various practical factors, such as environmental dynamics, intentional interference, and unauthorized transmission, hinder it from wide deployment. The recently released FCC rules suggest participatory real-time spectrum sensing can greatly improve the spectrum utilization efficiency for database-driven spectrum sharing, which forms a new paradigm, hybrid dynamic spectrum sharing. However, the frequent information exchanged between secondary users and spectrum database can be easily intercepted and manipulated by malicious users, which not only downgrades the spectrum efficiency but also incurs severe security breaches to the hybrid dynamic spectrum access system. This project will explore new paradigms of safeguarding the future cognitive radio system with focus on non-compliance behavior detection. The success of this project will serve as a key enabler to provide reliable wireless communication in the near future.

This project will investigate several fundamental security challenges in the newly defined hybrid dynamic spectrum access. This first research task will identify new attack models that compromise the spectrum efficiency and then provide countermeasures adapted to future wireless systems. Due to the inherent nature of database-driven spectrum access, primary user emulation (PUE) attackers can retrieve the spectrum availability information to either perform as the incumbent user (IU) when it is not present, or try to increase secondary users' transmission power to interfere with present IUs. Featuring the sensing results stored in the database, novel detection schemes will be designed to mitigate the influence brought by the attack. The second research task leverages physical-layer approaches to detect unauthorized access under different channel models. To address this issue, channel availability information will be used to detect malicious secondary users. Meanwhile, the detection mechanisms will be developed with joint consideration on practicality and efficiency. Additionally, the project includes strong validation component that combines simulation study, prototyping, and experimentation. It will thus provide an effective training ground for interdisciplinary subjects including wireless networks, wireless communication, and cybersecurity, all of which are critical to diversified professionals for future national work force.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To tackle the ever-increasing spectrum scarcity issue, dynamic spectrum access is envisioned as a set of promising new spectrum management paradigms. Although it has enabled the opportunistic access of underutilized licensed bands, various practical factors, such as environmental dynamics, intentional interference, and unauthorized transmission, hinder it from wide deployment.

 

The FCC rules suggest participatory real-time spectrum sensing can greatly improve the spectrum utilization efficiency for database-driven spectrum sharing, which forms a new paradigm, hybrid dynamic spectrum sharing. However, the information exchanged between secondary users and spectrum database will cause severe security breaches brought by malicious behaviors. This EAGER project has conducted a thorough study on identifying new malicious behaviors and further designing countermeasures to ensure the security in hybrid dynamic spectrum access. By leveraging private equality test technique and locality sensitive hashing, the team has developed privacy-preserving mechanism to ensure users will not lose their query privacy when requesting to the database-driven dynamic spectrum access. One of the critical security concerns in future hybrid dynamic spectrum sharing paradigm is the misuse of spectrum resources from multiple secondary users. The PI and his team investigated a secure and optimized unauthorized secondary user detection scheme by embedding ``permit bits’’ for authorized users. This pure physical-layer designs will greatly enhance the practicality in implementing security schemes in spectrum sharing. This line of research has been focusing on a dynamic range of wireless environment, hence broadening its applicability in future wireless systems. Besides, to better provide authenticity of transmitted data, the PI has extended the research to securing the IoT communication in the overlapping spectrum. Specifically, a new physical-layer attack, signal emulation attack in the heterogenous IoT environments, has been identified. This new attack can compromise the crowdsensing data from diverse commercial-off-the-shelf IoT devices. The PI has proposed and evaluated different physical-layer defensive mechanisms to prevent spectrum misuse by malicious secondary users. The performance of hybrid dynamic spectrum access also highly relies on the way that data is transmitted, in which the current data traffic always exacerbates the energy consumption on cellular service provider. To alleviate the traffic and further vacant the precious spectrum bands, the PI proposed a social-aware data offloading scheme to alleviate the burden during the data transmission, greatly enhancing the stability of the future wireless system. All the above results have been experimentally verified using real-world datafiles.

 

The developed physical-layer misuse detection schemes can greatly enhance the security when multiple users participated in sensing and using the available spectrum. Meanwhile, the mobile data offloading schemes can relieve the data traffic from the infrastructure to users, and further reduce the network congestion in crowded areas, which will make significant progress and generate more business opportunities in building future smart cities. The investigation on potential wireless attacks to IoT devices can also provide insight for future wireless device manufacturing. The proposed defensive mechanisms can be generally deployed in many wireless application scenarios, such as industrial IoT, smart agriculture, and smart healthcare. During this project duration, the PI has supported three Ph.D. students, in which two of them have already graduated and one female Ph.D. graduate become an assistant professor at Department of Computer Science, Florida State University. Under the PI’s supervision, the team has produced 9 high-quality technical papers published in highly reputable venues in research community. The team also share the technical results to a broader range of students at Binghamton University and Clemson University.
